Welcome to Miniproject’s documentation!

Miniproject’s API app.py

app.app.calculate_distance(lat1, lon1, lat2, lon2)[source]

Function to calculate the distance between two geographical points.

Parameters: lat1 (float): Latitude of the first point. lon1 (float): Longitude of the first point. lat2 (float): Latitude of the second point. lon2 (float): Longitude of the second point.

Returns: dict: A dictionary containing the distance in kilometers.

app.app.fetch_coordinates(city_name)[source]

Function to fetch the coordinates of a given city using the Nominatim OpenStreetMap API.

Parameters: city_name (str): The name of the city to find coordinates for.

Returns: dict: A dictionary containing the latitude and longitude of the city.

Raises: ValueError: If the city is not found or there is an error in the API request.

app.app.get_coordinates()[source]

API endpoint to get the coordinates of a given city.

Parameters: city_name (str): The name of the city to find coordinates for.

Returns: dict: A dictionary containing the latitude and longitude of the city.

app.app.get_distance()[source]

API endpoint to calculate the distance between two geographical points.

Parameters: lat1 (float): Latitude of the first point. lon1 (float): Longitude of the first point. lat2 (float): Latitude of the second point. lon2 (float): Longitude of the second point.

Returns: dict: A dictionary containing the distance in kilometers.

Miniproject’s API test_app.py

app.test_app.client()[source]

Pytest fixture to set up the test client for the Flask app.

Yields:

client – A Flask test client.

app.test_app.test_get_coordinates_failure(client)[source]

Test case to verify the failure response of the get_coordinates endpoint for an unknown city.

Parameters:

client – The Flask test client.

Asserts:

  • The response status code is 404 (Not Found).

app.test_app.test_get_coordinates_success(client)[source]

Test case to verify the successful response of the get_coordinates endpoint.

Parameters:

client – The Flask test client.

Asserts:

  • The response status code is 200 (OK).

  • The response JSON contains ‘latitude’.

  • The response JSON contains ‘longitude’.

app.test_app.test_get_distance_failure(client)[source]

Test case to verify the failure response of the get_distance endpoint when parameters are missing.

Parameters:

client – The Flask test client.

Asserts:

  • The response status code is 400 (Bad Request).

app.test_app.test_get_distance_success(client)[source]

Test case to verify the successful response of the get_distance endpoint.

Parameters:

client – The Flask test client.

Asserts:

  • The response status code is 200 (OK).

  • The response JSON contains ‘distance’.

  • The distance value is non-negative.

app.test_app.test_the_result_is_correct_for_all_inputs_get_coordinates(client, city_name, expected_lat, expected_lon)[source]

Parameterized test case to verify the get_coordinates endpoint for multiple cities.

Parameters:

  • client – The Flask test client.

  • city_name – The name of the city to get coordinates for.

  • expected_lat – The expected latitude of the city.

  • expected_lon – The expected longitude of the city.

Asserts:

  • The response status code is 200 (OK).

  • The latitude value is within 1km tolerance of the expected latitude.

  • The longitude value is within 1km tolerance of the expected longitude.

app.test_app.test_the_result_is_correct_for_all_inputs_get_distance(client, lat1, lon1, lat2, lon2, expected_distance)[source]

Parameterized test case to verify the get_distance endpoint for multiple pairs of coordinates.

Parameters:

  • client – The Flask test client.

  • lat1 – The latitude of the first point.

  • lon1 – The longitude of the first point.

  • lat2 – The latitude of the second point.

  • lon2 – The longitude of the second point.

  • expected_distance – The expected distance between the two points.

Asserts:

  • The response status code is 200 (OK).

  • The distance value is within 5km tolerance of the expected distance.
